snippet: Judges routinely jail people to make them pay fines even when they have no money to pay, flouting the Constitution, the law and basic fairness.
abstract: Editorial contends that judges routinely jail people to make them pay fines, even when they have no money to pay, violating several Supreme Court rulings and a basic tenet of the American legal system; argues that the problem has worsened in recent years as budget-strapped state courts look for additional sources of revenue; calls on state judicial leaders to intervene.
lead_paragraph: Judges routinely jail people to make them pay fines even when they have no money to pay, flouting the Constitution, the law and basic fairness.
